awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Data-driven Koopman Operator Techniques for Chaotic and Non-Autonomous Dynamical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop data-driven Koopman methodologies for analyzing and identifying spectral properties of coherent patterns and predicting their dynamical evolutions in dynamical systems with both oscillatory modes and continuous spectrum as well subject to secular trends. Koopman operators were derived in the early 1930s and used to prove an important theorem on the behavior of idealized dynamical systems. But they remained largely unknown beyond dynamical systems theory until the early 2000s, when their usefulness for complicated, data intensive problems was recognized. Since then, the idea of Koopman operators in combination with machine learning algorithms has been applied to various problems in fluid dynamics, stability analysis of power networks, the development of financial trading algorithms, and brain activity research. Like these applications, climate research is often data-driven and involves analysis of a complex system, thus Koopman operators could be a valuable addition to the climate research toolkit. 

The advances in pattern extraction and predictive capabilities for complex systems stemming from this project will have great impacts in the field of nonlinear dynamical systems and will be applicable to various disciplines that deal with time-evolving phenomena, from climate science, fluid dynamics, to neuroscience and economics. The project will contribute towards STEM workforce development through the training of a postdoc and new course development for on data-driven dynamical systems modeling at Principal Investigator's home institution.

This project will advance machine learning techniques and spectral Galerkin methods for identifying Koopman eigen-frequencies and eigenfunctions of complex dynamical systems that are subject to both stochastic forcing and external forcing (such as the Earth's climate system) from time series and spatiotemporal data without knowledge of the underlying governing equations and boundary conditions. The team will apply the data-driven methods to climate simulations of El Nino Southern Oscillation to study the interactions of natural variability and forced response of the climate system. This will demonstrate the ability of the methods to reveal and predict many aspects of the temporal evolutions of dominant modes in data, which cannot be achieved from conventional covariance-based methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An important problem in modern applied science is characterizing and predicting the behavior of complex dynamical phenomena. Examples include the circulation of the Earth's atmosphere and oceans, the folding of proteins, and the evolution of species populations in an ecosystem. In these and many other examples, the dynamics is oftentimes chaotic, meaning that small perturbations of the system state interact in complicated (nonlinear) ways, leading to large, unpredictable effects in the longer term. A familiar application impacted by chaotic dynamics is weather forecasting, where the ability to predict individual weather events such as storms diminishes after a period of one to two weeks.

Yet, even though predicting individual events may be operationally impossible, many complex systems exhibit coherent patterns, which act as building blocks around which chaotic dynamics is organized. An example from climate dynamics is the El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO), which is a large-scale oscillatory pattern with an approximate period of 4-5 years. ENSO is manifested by episodes of warm or cold sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies, called El Niño and La Niña events, respectively. During El Niños/La Niñas, the atmospheric and oceanic circulations change in a measurable way, providing a source of predictability for the statistics of the weather (e.g., precipitation over a given season) on longer timescales than individual events. Identifying coherent patterns such as ENSO is thus important for improving forecasting capabilities, and more broadly for improving our scientific understanding of complex phenomena.

In response, the principal objective of this project was to develop mathematical and computational techniques for identification and prediction of coherent patterns in complex systems and apply these methods to problems in climate dynamics. Our approach was based on two pillars: ergodic theory and data science. Ergodic theory is the branch of mathematics that studies the statistical behavior of complex systems. It provides a rigorous framework to identify coherent patterns by studying how observables, i.e., quantities that can be measured such as SST, evolve in time. Ergodic theory describes the evolution of observables using so-called Koopman operators, which have an associated notion of spectrum and coherent observables (akin to the spectrum of frequencies generated by a musical instrument). Meanwhile, data science provides the mathematical and computational tools to implement the ergodic-theoric constructs using empirical measurements such as historical climate data. Our research explored novel combinations of ideas from the two fields, leading to new methods for analysis and forecasting of data generated by complex systems:

  • We developed a new class of techniques that provably approximate the spectrum of the Koopman operator from time series data. These methods addressed a longstanding problem in the field, namely, how to appropriately represent Koopman operators with continuous spectra. In broad terms, rather than exhibiting a denumerable set of frequencies (analogous to individual tones of a well-tuned musical instrument) a chaotic system exhibits a continuum of frequencies, and identifying the frequencies associated with coherent observables within this continuum is a challenging mathematical and computational problem. Our approach employed kernel methods to discretize the Koopman spectrum and isolate the frequencies associated with coherent observables in the continuum.
  • We developed a framework for data-driven forecasting of observables. Our approach uses historical observations of the system to build an approximation of the Koopman operator that can be used to predict the future evolution of any observable of interest. These predictions were shown to be optimal (in the sense of root mean square error) in the asymptotic limit of large training datasets.
  • We applied our framework to problems in climate dynamics. In Figure 1, spectral analysis of the Koopman operator is employed to identify the ENSO lifecycle from SST data. In Figure 2, our forecasting framework is applied to predict the historic 2015/16 El Niño up to six months in advance.
  • In the final phases of the project, we generalized our framework to non-autonomous dynamical systems, i.e., systems subjected to external influences. Our primary motivation is climate change, where it is important to objectively disambiguate between natural variability of the system and its response to anthropogenic and natural external factors. We have shown that the operator-theoretic techniques developed under the project are capable of separating trends (such as climate change) from other coherent observables due to natural variability (such as ENSO). We expect that these methods will provide an effective tool for climate change attribution in the observational record, as well as in climate simulations.         

Besides its intellectual merit, the project had broader impacts by contributing to STEM workforce development. In total, two undergraduate students, three PhD students, and two postdoctoral researchers participated in the project and received training from the PI. In addition, the project is likely to benefit society across the spectrum of activities dealing with complex, time-evolving phenomena. As discussed above, climate and weather forecasting are two application domains with high societal impacts directly addressed by the project.
